hackathon-eligibility: If you applied to PennApps XV,
hackathon-requirements: Make your project, submit your hack to Devpost and attend the PennApps expo to show off what you built. You
hackathon-rules: Only teams comprised wholly of eligible participants that submit their hacks to this DevPost, and then go on to demo their hack at the PennApps expo can win prizes.

hackathon-prizes.prize-content: Oculus Rift + Nintendo Switch + GoPro Session; Lutron Plug-In Dimmer Kit.
Nintendo Switch + GoPro Session
Nintendo Switch
Hacks that have applications in wellness, medicine and healthcare. Prize: NeuroSky Mindwave Mobile: Brainwave Starter Kit and Surface Pro 4s.
Hacks that have applications in education.Prize: Patagonia backpack & 1 TB external hard drive.
Hacks where the main focus is on hardware. Prize: Hardware kits for each team member
Hacks where the main focus is on Virtual/Augmented Reality. Prizes: Logitech Z623 200 Watt Home Speaker System + Amazon Echo Dot
Hacks with a primary goal geared towards issues of social or civic impact, or focus on a local community. Prizes: Logitech Z623 200 Watt Home Speaker System + Amazon Echo Dot
hackathon-prizes.prize-title: PennApps Route | Best Social/Civic Hacking Hack

hackathon-prizes.prize-content: Presented by Capital One. Winners will receive $400 Amazon gift cards each.
hackathon-prizes.prize-title: Best Use of the Capital One API - Nessie

hackathon-prizes.prize-content: Presented by Datto. Winners will receive $200 gift cards each.

Given to the hack which demonstrates a good integration between hardware and software. Presented by Lutron. Winners will receive Lutron Caséta Wireless Smart Lighting Plug-in Lamp Dimmer Kits (HomeKit-enabled).

Presented by 1517 Fund. This prize package, including a $1K grant, $5K in AWS credits, and ongoing mentorship will go to the team that creates a unique and creative product that they'd like to bring to market.
Presented by NameCheap. Winners will receive $150 credit in their NameCheap accounts.
hackathon-prizes.prize-title: Best Domain Name Registered in PennApps XV

hackathon-prizes.prize-content: Presented by Button. The prize will go to the hack that best adds a Button to their iOS , Android, or mobile web app. Each winning team member will get an Amazon echo (or similarly priced prize of the team member's choice).
Presented by L3 Technologies. Prize: Cheerwing Syma X5SW-V3 FPV for each team member
Presented by Two Sigma. Given to the hack that displays the best use of Beaker or best use of data analysis. Prize: $200 AMEX Gift Cards per team member.
hackathon-prizes.prize-title: Best Data Science Project/Best Use of Beaker

hackathon-prizes.prize-content: Given to the best space-related hack. Prize: Google Homes
Give to the hack displaying the best user experience. Prize: Google Homes
Given to the hack that displays the most use to students. Prize: Logitech Z623 200 Watt Home Speaker System
It's a surprise!!!
Presented by AddLab. Prize: $50 in 3D Printing Credit.
hackathon-prizes.prize-title: Best Use of Rapid Prototyping, sponsored by AddLab

hackathon-location-google-maps: https://maps.google.com/?q=220 S 33rd St, Philadelphia, PA 19104, USA

hackathon-judging-criteria.judging-criterion: Is the hack technically interesting or difficult? Is it just some lipstick on an API, or were there real technical challenges to surmount? This is the most important criterion that your hack will be judged upon for the general prizes.
Is the hack more than just another generic social/mobile/local app? Does it do something entirely novel, or at least take a fresh approach to an old problem?
Is the hack usable in its current state? Is the user experience smooth? Does everything appear to work? Is it well designed?
Is the hack practical? Is it something people would actually use? Does it fulfill a real need people have?
